earch problem.

an a single 
output.

biases and 
learning

 across the 
> substrate 
> > just like weights.

> > However, the one =
problem that comes up with nodes is that node-
> centric 
> > properties ar=
e overspecified by a 4D CPPN because nodes are 
> specified 
> > by only tw=
o dimensions (that is, they are points in space rather 
> than 
> > lines).=
  Therefore, you have to set a convention for when to 
read 
> the 
> > val=
ue of a node-centric output and assign it to a node.  For 
> example,

you could say that the node at x1 y1 is set to the value of the 
> node 
> =
> output only when x2 y2 are both zero.  Of course there are many 
> > alte=
rnative ways it could be done, but some convention must be 
> set.

> I=
 will try to do the following.. the CPPN will have 2 more 
outputs, 
> that=
 will specity the time constant and bias of THE SECOND node,

I think this shouldn't hurt performance.. But I guess 
it
